awd_titl_txt: Promoting Undergraduate STEM Retention through Self-Efficacy
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the Carroll University Pro-STEM Initiative: Promoting STEM Retention through Self-Efficacy will provide support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at Carroll University. The project will fund 128 scholarships over five years for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in applied physics, biochemistry, chemistry, computer science, and mathematics. To promote academic success and retention within these STEM majors, the program will: (1) incorporate self-efficacy building strategies in general education courses of Carroll University's liberal arts curriculum, (2) foster support of project goals through a faculty professional learning community populated by those who teach first-year courses in the targeted fields, and (3) use peer-led study groups and community building activities that support self-efficacy and retention.

This project will integrate focused instruction that promotes self-efficacy development into foundational general education courses for first year students.  It will examine whether or not this instruction improves persistence in the targeted STEM majors, and if so how it does so.  Building on self-efficacy research, this project applies Habits of Mind strategies and practices (e.g., persisting, thinking flexibly metacognition, striving for accuracy, and questioning and posing problems) to help students build academic skills and self-awareness.  Activities of the project contribute to the knowledge base on STEM retention and student academic success. The results will further serve as a model to aid other small schools in increasing completion rates and effectively preparing students for success beyond college.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF S-STEM project was focused on increasing STEM graduation rates and providing financial support to typically underrepresented STEM Scholars. In total it funded 67 scholarships over five years (February 2018 to January 2023) for students pursuing bachelor’s degrees in calculus-based STEM majors at Carroll University.  To increase persistence/retention in these majors, scholars took a general education first-semester seminar course that developed student self-efficacy, attended weekly study-group meetings, participated in biweekly spring-semester meetings that supported themes from the fall seminar, and attended occasional social activities. In addition, faculty within the targeted majors were invited to participate in a faculty learning seminar, where discussions focused on self-efficacy, retention, and authentic assessment were aimed at enhancing student teaching methodology.

Year one retention within the targeted majors was lower for scholars (57.6%, 19 of 33), than overall 74.8% (193 of 258) retention. Just when retention was leveling out the project was stymied by the pandemic.  Despite pandemic interruptions regular focus groups with students suggest that this sort of project has and would continue to provide favorable outcomes for student persistence and retention in STEM majors. Specifically, student response was positive to the impact of being placed in like cohortts while also focusing on self-efficacy through metacognitive practices and regular study-group opportunities.  The social activities, due to pandemic interruption, were too sporadic to impact scholars meaningfully and have any real impact.

The faculty learning community  had early buy-in, with meetings focused on developing student self-efficacy, as it is a known critical component to STEM success.  Discussions included how success in many STEM majors is largely influenced by students’ lack of self-efficacy, and retention within these majors.  The pandemic, however, put a hold on regular meetings.  To rekindle interest, the final year of the FLC involved a workshop on authentic assessment, culminating in some faculty implementing authentic assessment activities in fall 2022 courses.  Feedback here from faculty was positive, in that authentic assessment was informative and constructive.


Last Modified: 05/30/2023
Modified by: John Symms
